Key Match Events: Immanuel Quickley scored 12 of his 21 points in the fourth quarter.
Ochai Agbaji had another strong game, tying Quickley’s 21 points while filling up the stat sheet with seven boards, three dimes, and two steals.
Gradey Dick and RJ Barrett had a relatively quiet night, scoring 15 and 13 points respectively.
Bruno Fernando provided the defense and energy, while the big three Quickley, Agbaji and Chris Boucher got the Raptors to tie the game at 93.
Norman Powell’s trifecta gave the Clippers a 100-95 lead with two minutes left.
Quickley knotted the game at 102 with 35 seconds remaining.
Powell split his freebie, but Quickley missed his layup on the other end.
Harden was sent to the line with 28 seconds remaining, splitting his freebies and giving the Clippers a two-point lead.
RJ Barrett missed his layup, and they sent Powell to the line with 8.1 seconds remaining. Powell split his freebies again, giving the Clippers a 105-102 lead.
Coach Darko called for time and drew up for Poeltl to get the inbounds pass, not once, but twice, as the Clippers strategically wanted to ‘foul up three.’
Poeltl missed the shot, and that’s the game.
Post-Match Reflections: The Raptors drop their third straight loss, tanking their record to 2-8 through ten games, and first team in the NBA to lose 8 games. They are also winless on the road (0-5).
Miscellaneous Highlights: Bruno Fernando was a revelation in this game, as he infused the team with the much-needed energy that allowed the Raptors to mount an 18-6 run in the fourth to tie the game.
Ivica Zubac thoroughly outplayed Jakob Poeltl, driving coach Darko Rajakovic to bench Poeltl for most of the fourth quarter to keep him fresh until coach Darko needed a hero to win the game.
The Clippers’ foul-bait duo Norman Powell and his Robin James Harden led all scorers with 24 points apiece, combining for 22 free throws in this game, 1 more than the Raptors combined.
